questions.answer_description:
USB audio and video devices certified for Microsoft Teams.
The peripherals certification program ensures USB peripherals (such as headsets, speakerphones, webcams, and monitors) offer rich audio or video quality.
Certified devices work (plug & play) with no extra configuration required, and offer call control with Microsoft Teams and Skype for Business. The products provide a great experience for end users and administrators.
Certified devices include:

Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/devices/usb-devices

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D (Microsoft Teams-certified handsets)
Microsoft-certified headsets can't not support following:
Can access the Teams directory for dial by name.
Can be administered remotely.

comments.content: It's talking about hot desking. You wouldn't put a user in a room with an MTR. Also, there is no way to configure hot desking on a teams for android or windows. Just not possible.

discussion.content: Answer is C. You cant manage a headset, handset remotely which is the second requirement
I also vote for D. For 550 usd you can get a Crestron Flex 8 that supports hot desking, corporate directory access
I'm thinking D also. A headset by itself needs a PC or a phone to work with it.

comments.content:
The answer it says "USB audio and video devices certified for Microsoft Teams."
The unique "Skype for Business with upgrade to Microsoft Teams" at MS Website are headset.
Sorry, Answer is correct. D is wrong

questions.question_text:
You have an analog phone system.
You plan to migrate to Microsoft Teams Phone.
You need to recommend devices for common area phones that any user can use. The solution must meet the following requirements:
✑ Can access the Teams directory for dial by name.
Can be administered remotely.
//IMG//

✑ Can place and pick up calls.
✑ Support hot desking.
✑ Minimize costs.
Which type of devices should you recommend?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I would say B is correct answer. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/cqd-upload-tenant-building-data - endpoint file contains information on end user devices.

Selected Answer: D
The Endpoint data file is used to provide information about the devices that are being used in the environment, including the device name, IP address, and user information. This data is used to correlate with call quality metrics and to provide more detailed information about the sources of call quality issues.==D
i will not go with B coz :
uploading the Building data file in the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard, is used to provide information about the physical location of devices, which can be used to identify trends in call quality issues across different locations. It is not directly related to reviewing Wired Inside data.

Selected Answer: B
Also going with B.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/cqd-data-and-reports#inside-versus-outside

questions.question_text:
You have a Teams Phone deployment.

When you review the Server - Client summary reports in Teams, you discover that Wired Inside data is unavailable as shown in the following exhibit.

//IMG//


You need to review the monthly and daily trends in the reports.

What should you do?

choices.A: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, configure the network topology.
choices.D: From the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard, upload the Endpoint data file.
choices.B: From the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard, upload the Building data file.
choices.C: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, upload reporting labels.

choices.D: Add a configuration profile for the IP phones.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is Correct

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/alerts/device-health-status
You can also get notifications with an external webhook (optional). Specify an external public webhook URL in the webhook section where a JSON notification payload will be sent. 

The notification payload, via webhooks, can be integrated with other systems in your organization to create custom workflows.

questions.question_text:
Your company uses a third-party ticketing system.
You need to send an alert to the ticketing system when an IP phone goes offline.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
1)Enable logging in the settings of the app
2)Collect the logs by right-clicking the Teams notification icon
3)Send media logs to Teams.

comments.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/log-files#media-logs

Therein states: Media logs contain diagnostic data about audio, video, and screen sharing in Teams meetings. They are required for support cases that are linked to call-related issues. 

Because this is related to call quality, media logs are required. Desktop logs, also known as bootstrapper logs, contain log data that occurs between the desktop client and the browser.

discussion.content:
1. Enable logging for meeting diagnostics
2. Collect support files
3. Send the Desktop logs to Microsoft support
(you only send media logs if requested by microsoft)

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

A user uses the Microsoft Teams client on a Windows device.

The user reports call quality issues.

You need to send the diagnostics logs to Microsoft support to troubleshoot the issues.

Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

choices.C: From the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard, select Tenant Data Upload and upload a CSV file that contains the new network site only.
choices.B: From Network planner in the Microsoft Teams admin center, add a new persona.
choices.A: From Network planner in the Microsoft Teams admin center, modify an existing network plan.
choices.D: From the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard, select Tenant Data Upload and upload a CSV file that contains all the network sites.
choices.E: From Network planner in the Microsoft Teams admin center, add a new network plan.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is Correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You deploy a new network site.
You discover that the new site is not listed in location-based reports. Other sites appear in the reports.
You need to ensure that all the sites appear in the reports.
What should you do?
